channel.title: Web Based IDE?
channel.description:
Id like to use java at school, however, everything iv tried is blocked :|
SIDE is great, but my school doesnt let people run jar files
does anyone know of a web based java IDE, one that you just go to the website and an applet loads, where you do not have to download anything
my school DOES have JRE, but NOT JDK and command prompt is inaccessable anyway
i tried searching for one on google, but nothing came up, im not even sure such a thing exists.
please dont say "wait till you get home", i came here for help, not smart comments

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @ada ada
item.description:
@ada wrote:

To get command prompt, try making a shortcut to “command.com” somewhere. It works at our school, where they blocked command prompt

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

ye i would REALLY like this also. if this is possible then i can learn more java at school instead of javascript <eeww

the admins dont trust us with batch, cmd, exe and other Miscellaneous program files. since SIDE is opensource i will try and get it to embed to a webpage. the only problem would be executing the .class files. i could possibly make it upload to the server and dynamically execute it there however dont know :s

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

no we cant run Batch files ether

i did try JSmooth, but the type of file i made didnt work (i even made a cute mopar picture for the icon ;D), it just closed SIDE half a second after it opened, ill play around with some options, maybe i will be able to get it to work

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Oh, also, if you want to run SIDE from school, check out JSmooth. JSmooth wraps jar files into a exe file (which should hopefully run) - it also either packages a bare minimum version if your current jre into the exe or searches for the location of the installed jre on the running system (I forget which).

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Are you able to create .bat files. Many times the school admins will disable command prompt access however, they don’t disable the running of .bat files. Just create a text file, give it the .bat extension and run it.

If you need a ‘seed’ of junk to throw into the .bat file, here:

REM Prints environment variables.. use this to find the jre home..
@echo off
set
pause

If you get a command window with environment variables, then you should not have any problem running java or javaw.

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

thanks BobDole, that was very useful i havent found a way run the class files, but at least i can check if they compile

Read full topic

import java.util.jar.*;
Bot.log(“Binary form != Jar form.”);
System.exit(0);

item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

sif I am.

What other forms to you leave class files as?

(this is disregarding dynamically compiled class files, as they urm, dont count. But any file really falls under binary form)

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_

Bollocks are you not, you back for good mutha fucka.

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

im not sure what you mean. What are you talking about regarding uploaded classes and dynamic classloading.

Uploading the results of the compile? (0_o) the applet works locally so wouldnt have an effect on the serverside but yes it would require calls to the security manager depending on what operations its trying to execute.

Heh im not going to be here for long =p

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

As an applet though…you can’t safely upload the compiled class to the server without setting up some serverside script (which is the long-winded part)…and I can’t really think of an alternative besides that than accessing the client’s drive.

Btw, nice to see you’ve re-appeared Sean

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

dynamically loading classes is fine aslong as their location is the same as the codebase.

What I did in college was carry around a cd with a batch file, emacs, the jdk, jee and various libraries I used on a daily basis with me. Running the batch file would setup any environemental variables I needed and launch emacs, and copy any tempoary files over.

Pwnt, I wrote a http proxy at college (as a servlet) with url recogniring, image streaming etc via this stuff. Pwned the block ftw (ok theres many pre existing stuff in college but I felt like coding so suck me nob)

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Here’s a link to an online java compiler in case its of any use: http://www.innovation.ch/java/java_compile.html

[quote=“Iamadam, post:4, topic:30768”]So, embed SIDE to a webpage, use that to code. If it doesn’t compile, use the site mopman posted.
Sounds like fun, I might give it a go as well.[/quote]
Unless you sign the applet, I don’t think it would work as SIDE access the compiled classes by dynamically loading the classes…I guess it would be possible, but a bit long winded imo

Read full topic

item.title: Web Based IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Hmm. I don’t know of any.
Im thinking though, maybe embed SIDE to an applet or something? I’m not sure if an applet gives sufficient security privialages though - compiling and executing your code my just not be possible.

Read full topic
